content: इदं {%<ab>pron. a.</ab>%} [अयं {%<ab>m.</ab>%}, इयं {%<ab>f.</ab>%}, इदं {%<ab>n.</ab>%}] {@--1@} This here, referring to something near the speaker; (इदमस्तु संनिकृष्टं रूपं); इदं तत्… इति यदुच्यते <ls>Ś. 5</ls> here is the truth of the saying. {@--2@} Present, seen; the nominative forms are used with verbs in the sense of ‘here’; इयमस्मि here am I; so इमे स्मः; अयमागच्छामि here I come. {@--3@} It often refers to something immediately following, while एतद् refers to what precedes; अनुकल्पस्त्वयं ज्ञेयः सदा सद्भिरनुष्टितः . <ls>Ms. 3. 147</ls> (अयं = वक्ष्यमाणः <ls>Kull.</ls>); श्रुत्वैतदिदमूचुः. {@--4@} It occurs connected with यत्, तत्, एतद्, अदस्, किं or a personal pronoun, either to point out anything more distinctly and emphatically, or sometimes pleonastically; कोयमाचरत्यविनयं <ls>Ś. 1. 25</ls>; सेयं, सोयं, this here; so इमास्ताः; अयमहं भोः <ls>Ś. 4</ls> ho, here am I. {%--<ab>ind.</ab>%} <ab>Ved.</ab> {@--1@} Here, to this place. {@--2@} Now. {@--3@} There. {@--4@} With these words, herewith.
